Hovey — 5
At the moment, the Republicans, Liberals and Social Democrats are
engaged in long discussions on whether it is possible for them to agree on
a common political program and thus form an influential coalition} a demo¬
cratic alternative to the Christian Democratic government.
At the moment, the Christian Democracy — a widely-based, hetero¬
genous party, like our own, in many respects — is showing new evidences of
straining at its seams, with only the prestige and power of Alolde de
Casper1 holding it together.
And while these things are going on, the Communists relentlessly
stay on the Job of building a party. They talk language ordinary Italians
understand} they talk unceasingly about everyday problems and Issues that
concern ordinary Italians.
It is surely this energy, more even than the social and economic
conditions of Italy, that has enabled the Italian Communist party to sur¬
vive many major defeats in this postwar period but come beck stronger than
ever. It is this energy that has enabled a party of two million members
and a hard cor© of perhaps 200,000 to poll — with its Socialist allies —
a vote of 9*5 million.
And as Communism gains, Italian democracy loses, any way one looks
at it. Aa Communism gains, its supporters among the Italian workers feel
more Isolated than ever from their government} and that government, in turn,
feels more Isolated from them. The results have been apparent in a rash of
serious strikes in recent weeks and months. Some believe the results are
apparent, too, in a turn to the right by the Pella government, which must
depend increasingly on the support of the Monarchists to survive.
As I drove to the studios to record this program I passed a new
series of Communist party posters. They say that the Hon. Di Vittorio will
address a meeting of the activists of the CGIL — the big labor union — at
the Manzoni theater on Sunday. Anyone interested is invited to attend.
One gets the feeling that only when the middle road parties are
willing to work as hard as the Communists on all fronts — including the
battle of the posters — will the future of Italian democracy be secure.
Graham Hovey, signing another Letter from Italy. This program
was recorded in the Rome studios of Radio Italians for the National
Association of Educational Broadcasters — and this isthe NAEB network.
